title: AB 250
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward," "distant site," "health care provider," and "originating site." Telehealth is the delivery of healthcare services through technology for remote patient care, including real-time interactions and asynchronous transfers. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, the provider must inform the patient, obtain consent, and document it. Patients can still receive in-person care if they agree to telehealth first. Non-compliance is considered unprofessional conduct. This section does not change a provider's scope of practice or allow unauthorized healthcare delivery. (f) Laws on health information confidentiality and patient rights apply to telehealth. (g) Excludes patients under Department of Corrections jurisdiction. (h) Hospitals can grant privileges to telehealth providers based on medical staff recommendations. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure exams must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks, with supervised hours after obtaining a master's or doctoral degree. The applicant must complete 1,700 hours of supervised experience after obtaining a master's or doctoral degree, with a maximum of 1,300 hours allowed before completing the degree. No more than 750 hours of counseling and direct supervisor contact can be credited before completing the degree. Experience cannot be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. No experience can be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Additionally, a maximum of 1,000 hours of experience is allowed in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities. Professional enrichment activities for marriage and family therapy applicants include workshops, seminars, training sessions, and conferences approved by their supervisor. They can also participate in personal psychotherapy for up to 100 hours, with credit for three hours of experience per hour. Additionally, applicants can gain up to 500 hours of experience providing group therapy or counseling. For hours gained on or after January 1, 2012, applicants must have experience in administering psychological tests, client advocacy, diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, and providing personal psychotherapy or counseling via telehealth. (11) Up to 375 hours of counseling experience via telehealth, including personal psychotherapy and crisis counseling, are required. (12) Experience should involve working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. This requirement applies to hours gained from January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised to ensure counseling aligns with their training. Supervised experience can only be gained as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. This rule applies to hours gained after January 1, 2010. Interns seeking licensure must provide W-2 tax forms or a letter from their employer verifying volunteer work. Supervision requirements include one hour of direct contact per week for each work setting, with specific ratios for client contact to supervisor contact. An individual supervised after obtaining a qualifying degree must receive additional direct supervisor contact for every week with more than 10 hours of client contact. No more than six hours of supervision can be credited in a single week. Direct supervisor contact can be face-to-face on an individual basis or in a group of up to eight supervisees for at least one continuous hour. (5) Direct supervisor contact for a group of up to eight supervisees must last at least one continuous hour.
(6) Interns in certain settings can use real-time videoconferencing for weekly supervisor contact, ensuring client confidentiality.
(7) The supervisor must monitor all experience gained by a trainee as per regulations.
(8) Six hours of supervision per week can be credited starting from January 1, 2009.
(d) (1) Trainees can receive credit for supervised experience in settings that meet specific criteria. Trainees and interns can receive credit for supervised experience in settings that meet specific criteria, including providing mental health counseling, oversight to ensure work meets requirements, and not being a private practice owned by certain licensed professionals. Experience must be gained as part of the trainee's volunteer or employment position. Interns must also meet specific criteria for supervised experience in any setting. An intern can receive credit for supervised experience in a setting that provides mental health counseling and oversight to ensure work meets requirements. They cannot work in a private practice until registered. Employers are encouraged to provide fair remuneration to interns. Interns, whether paid or volunteers, should receive fair remuneration. In private practice, interns must be supervised by a licensee who meets specific requirements, except during supervisor's absence. Interns can only gain experience related to their volunteer or employment position. Interns must register with the board to gain credit for postdegree supervised experience towards licensure. Postdegree experience is credited towards licensure if the applicant applies for intern registration within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. Trainees, interns, and applicants cannot receive payment from patients or clients, only from their employers. Trainees and interns must perform services under the direction and control of their employer, including via telehealth. They cannot have a proprietary interest in their employer's business or pay for any obligations. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses incurred while providing services in a lawful work setting are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to verify expenses reimbursement. Each educational institution and supervisor should consider encouraging students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
